(4) In relation to funding under these programs, (a) how many applications were received from within the electoral divisions of (i) Chisholm, (ii) Aston, (iii) Deakin, (iv) Latrobe and (v) Casey, (b) what is the name of each organisation that submitted an application, (c) what was the purpose of the funding being sought in each case, (d) what was the value of funding sought in each case and (e) if the application was successful, (i) what level of funding was granted and (ii) in which federal electoral division is the organisation located.

(5) In relation to programs that do not provide for organisations to apply for funding, what was the level of expenditure for each program in the electoral divisions of (a) Chisholm, (b) Aston, (c) Deakin, (d) Latrobe and (e) Casey in (i) 1996-97, (ii) 1997-98, (iii) 1998-99, (iv) 1999-2000, (v) 2000-2001 and (vi) 2001-2002.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) (a) to (f) Funding for the âStrengthening and Supporting Families Coping With Illicit Drug Useâ measure of the National Illicit Drug Strategy commenced in 2000/01. Funding to 2001/02 is:

(3) Funding is provided to State and Territory Governments to develop and implement programs under the measure. State/Territory Governments may engage non-government organisations to deliver measures.
(a) Programs funded in each State and Territory are as follows:

New South Wales - The âFamily Supportâ program provides a range of services to support the families of young people coping with illicit drug use, including telephone advice and referral services, on-line information services, training programs for families and carers of drug users, and developing the capacity of community organisations to provide home visitation or local support.

Victoria - The âAbout Better Communication about Drugsâ program is a state-wide parent education initiative, to provide parents with skills and parenting practices to build positive and trusting relationships with their children, and help them prevent and/or cope with adolescent drug use.

Queensland - The âSupport for Indigenous Communitiesâ program aims to help Indigenous communities and community groups in South-East Queensland to provide support to families where a young person is using illicit drugs. The âParent Education and Healthâ program aims to increase the knowledge, coping skills and confidence of parents in helping a young person with drug issues.

South Australia - The âAboriginal Families Against Drugsâ program develops Kinship Support Service Plans, focussed on the extended family, providing intensive support, education, counselling and referral services to increase the social and emotional well-being of drug users and their families.

Western Australia - The âFamily Program Supporting Police Diversionâ supports Community Drug Service Teams to provide outreach and follow-up support to families of young people diverted by police into drug counselling or treatment programs.
Tasmania - The âFamily Supportâ program will provide appropriate, targeted and resourced interventions to families affected, or vulnerable to the harms, of drug use.

Northern Territory - The âFamilies Coping With Drug Use in Remote Communitiesâ program aims to support the needs of families with a young person coping with illicit drug use, by developing interventions that can be applied at a remote Indigenous community level.

Australian Capital Territory - The âParent Education and Supportâ program provides parents with skills to handle drug-related issues in the family context, and enhances the capacity of community service providers to deliver these skills.
(b)(a) to (f) Total funding to each State/Territory commenced in 2000/01 and over 2000/01 and 2001/02 is as follows:

(4) (a)(i) to (v)(b) to (d)(e)(i) and (ii) In Victoria, âAbout Better Communication about Drugsâ delivers drug education programs across urban and regional areas of Victoria. Programs will be delivered to Eastern and South Eastern areas of Melbourne, including the suburbs of Box Hill, Croydon, Mooroolbark, Springvale, Narre Warren, and Pakenham. Due to the nature of service delivery, it is not possible to estimate expenditure for the electorates of Casey, Deakin, Aston, LaTrobe and Chisholm.
(5) Not applicable.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

question.para: (1) Does the Minister administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations or businesses can apply for funding.

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Defence has two grant programs for which community organisations or businesses can apply for funding.

(a) The Defence Family Support Funding Program (FSFP) provides funds to Defence families to enable them to undertake family support projects at the local level that will assist them to overcome the impacts of mobility. It is also available to existing groups in the community composed of, or benefiting, Defence families.

subdebateinfo.title: Family and Community Services: Program Funding

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Children and Youth Services and the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

question.para: (1) Does the Minister administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations or businesses can apply for funding.
(2) If so, what are these programs.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.

entry.para: Commonwealth childcare programs:Disadvantaged Area Subsidy for Long Day Care Centres and Outside School Hours Care ServicesFamily Day Care, In-home Care and Outside School Hours Care One-off Set-up GrantsFamily Day Care and In-home Care Operational SubsidiesJobs Education and Training programFamily Day Care and In-home Care Regional Travel Assistance GrantPrivate Provider Incentives for long day care rural and remote centre operators

Funding programs are advertised periodically when new programs are established or existing programs are expanded. Communication methods such as the Department's website, child care news publications and service handbooks are used. Other funding within program types is advertised in targeted areas or promoted directly in writing to potentially eligible services.
Centrepay National No Interest Loan Scheme pilot program
Advertising is undertaken by the Council of Social Services of NSW and existing No Interest Loan Scheme organisation networks.

Funding under the Disability Employment Assistance program is provided on an ongoing basis to existing service providers. Funding for new services is advertised in relevant major newspapers and the internet

Employers are informed of available assistance under the Employer incentive Strategy when a person with a disability is employed by their organisation from a Disability Employment Service. Disability Recruitment Coordinators are also funded by the Commonwealth to inform large employers of the disability employment programs, including the Employer Incentive Strategy.

National Disability Conference funding is advertised in early March each year through an advertisement placed in the Australian Newspaper. Information is also made available on the Department of Family and Community Services Internet site.

Information on new funding opportunities for family relationships services is made available on the Department of Family and Community Services website at www.facs.gov.au/frb under current funding opportunities and through advertising in national newspapers.
Request for submissions for the programme were advertised in all national and major regional newspapers on 6 & 9 February 2002.
The Department invites project proposals from organisations in target locations.

The Strategy is promoted in a range of publications including:The Commonwealth Regional information booklet (pg 6) posted to every letterbox in August 2002Local Government Year BooksCommunity Kit - available through FaCS officesSFCS brochure - distributed widelyWebsite - @ http://www.facs.gov.au/cando1800 free call number 1800300125
Family Homelessness Prevention and Early Intervention Pilots
Funding for the Family Homelessness Prevention and Early Intervention Pilots was allocated through a tender process which called for applications through advertisements in the press.
Availability of funding for NHS Demonstration projects is advertised on the NHS website.
Advertisements sought funding applications from interested communities and organisations for three selection rounds of the Reconnect Program.

The initial distribution of Youth Activities Services (YAS) and Family Liaison Worker (FLW) programs were based on submissions from interested sponsoring organisations (such as local councils, community organisations or groups).
In September 2001, expressions of interest were sought from organisations interested in managing the Green Corps Program from July 2002 until June 2005.

A Request for Application for the provision of JPET services 2003-2006, was advertised through national newspapers on 20 July 2002. The Departments' internet site contained details of the business allocation process. The advertisement was also posted on youth-service focused email lists. In addition, all providers of FaCS youth services were advised by email on the day prior to the advertisement going to press.
Innovative and Collaborative Youth Servicing (ICYS) Pilots
The ICYS Pilots were advertised nationally on 29 September 2001.

answer.para: (4) I am not prepared to authorise the expenditure of resources and effort that would be involved to obtain this information.

Dr Nelson

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) SCHOOLS
Â· Special Education - Non-government Centre Support Programme
Â· National Literacy and Numeracy Strategies and Projects Programme
Â· Jobs Pathway Programme (JPP)
Â· Career and Transition (CAT) Pilots
Â· Partnership Outreach Education Model (POEM) Pilots

Â· Enterprise and Career Education Foundation (ECEF)
Â· Aboriginal Student Support and Parent Awareness (ASSPA)

Â· Vocational and Educational Guidance for Aboriginals Scheme (VEGAS)
Â· Indigenous Educational Strategic Initiatives Programme (IESIP).
SCIENCE
Â· The Innovation Access Programme (IAP)
Â· The National Innovation Awareness Strategy
Â· The Cooperative Research Centre Programme (CRC)
Â· The Major National Research Facilities (MNRF).
INTERNATIONAL
Â· The Professional Services Development Programme (previously known as the Industry Development Programme).
VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING
Â· The Strategic Intervention Programme (SIP)
Â· Industry Training Strategies Programme (ITSP) (and formerly (pre 2000) Educative Services)
Â· Group Training New Apprenticeships Targeted Initiatives Programme (GTNATIP)
Â· New Apprenticeships Access Programme (NAAP)
Â· IT Skills for Older Workers Programme
Â· The Workplace English Language and Literacy (WELL) Programme
Â· New Apprenticeships Support Services
Â· The Language, Literacy and Numeracy Programme (LLNP).
(3) SCHOOLS

All programmes listed at (2) are advertised through publications and/or the Department's website www.dest.gov.au, and also through State and Territory Departments which administer some of the programmes.
SCIENCE
National Innovation Awareness Strategy - Yes. A `Call for Proposals' is released.
The Innovation Access Programme â The IAP is advertised on a national basis through newspapers and electronic newsletters.

The Cooperative Research Centre Programme - The CRC Programme, when calling for new applications for funding, is advertised through major national newspapers and all significant State or Territory newspapers. Details on the Programme and its selection rounds can also be found at the following Internet address: www.crc.gov.au.

The Major National Research Facility Programme - The MNRF Programme, when calling for new applications for funding, is advertised through major national newspapers and all significant State or Territory newspapers. Details of successful applicants announced under the MNRF Programme can be found at the following Internet address: www.dest.gov.au/mnrf/.
INTERNATIONAL
The Professional Services Development Programme is promoted to peak professional bodies for whom the funds are available. The Department does not advertise the funding opportunity.

VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING
No advertising for the Strategic Intervention Programme (SIP).
Yes, advertising by open tender for the Industry Training Strategies Programme (ITSP).

There are no plans currently to advertise funding opportunities for the Group Training New Apprenticeships Targeted Initiatives Programme (GTNATIP). Was advertised previously from late 2000 to early 2001.

The New Apprenticeships Access Programme (NAAP) completed a competitive tender for brokers in June 2002, contracts are valid until October 2004. Organisations involved in the provision of training arrangements especially focused on New Apprenticeships can approach contracted brokers.
IT Skills for Older Workers was advertised in July 2002 by open tender for brokers and is now closed. Organisations involved in delivery of training may approach contracted brokers.

Advertisements for the Workplace English Language and Literacy (WELL) Programme are placed in major national newspapers inviting applications for funding. Generally, all applications are considered at this time, although applications may be considered outside the major funding round.
New Apprenticeships Support Services is publicly advertised through major newspapers, the New Apprenticeships Website www.newapprenticeships.gov.au and the Purchasing and Disposal, APS Gazette.
The tender for the Language, Literacy and Numeracy Programme (LLNP) was advertised nationally in all major newspapers, on Saturday 11 August 2001 and on Saturday 18 August 2001.
(4) I am not prepared to authorise the expenditure of resources and effort that would be involved in breaking down the information sought into the electoral divisions requested.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 2002:

quote.para: (1) Does the Minister administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations or businesses can apply for funding.
(2) If so, what are these programs.
(3) Does the Minister's Department advertise these funding opportunities.

(4) In the electoral divisions of (a) Chisholm, (b) Aston, (c) Deakin, (d) Latrobe and (e) Casey in (i) 1996-97, (ii) 1997-98, (iii) 1998-99, (iv) 1999-2000, (v) 2000-2001 and (vi) 2001-2002, for each of the programs listed in part (2), (A) what was the name and postal address of each organisation that sought funding from the Commonwealth, (B) what was the purpose of the funding sought in each case and (C) for successful applications, what was the level of funding provided.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes
(2) There are 4 funding programs that the Department of Veterans' Affairs administers. They are:

Â· Building Excellence in Support and Training (BEST) program - The aim of this program is to provide support and resources to ex-service organisation practitioners for pension and welfare work to assist veterans and widow(er)s.

Â· Veteran and Community Grants - These grants aim to maintain and improve the independence and quality of life of members of the veteran community. The grants provide funding for projects which promote healthier lifestyles and enhance health, support carers, reduce social isolation and assist veterans and war widow(er)s to remain in their own homes as long as possible. Projects may meet the needs of others in the community if there is sufficient capacity.

Â· Saluting Their Service - Saluting Their Service is the Federal Government's commemorations program. It aims to highlight the sacrifice and service of Australia's servicemen and women in wars, conflicts and peacekeeping operations since Federation and to promote appreciation and understanding of the role that those who have served have played in shaping the nation.

The program is designed to preserve our heritage from wars and conflicts and encourage community participation in commemorative events. It aims to involve people throughout the nation in a wide range of activities and projects.
Modest grants up to $4,000 for projects, including events and activities that meet the aims and objectives of Saluting Their Service, may be provided.

Funding assistance may be provided for the restoration, preservation and upgrading of community war memorials or, where no memorial exists in the town or suburb, the construction of a new memorial. Funding may also be provided for the restoration, preservation and interpretation of Australian wartime memorabilia for public display, commemorative plaques and honour boards for public display, commemoration of significant anniversaries of battles and other military operations and school initiatives, eg research projects involving local veterans.
Â· Grants-in-Aid - The aim of this program is to assist national ex-service organisations with their administration costs in recognition of the services that they provide to the ex-service community.
(3) Advertising of the 4 funding programs that the Department of Veterans' Affairs administers is outlined below:
Â· Building Excellence in Support and Training (BEST) Program - The BEST program is not advertised in the commercial media. However, the BEST program is promoted by:

- annual forums held by State Deputy Commissioners with various peak ex-service organisation representatives to address BEST funding for the coming financial year. From these forums, peak ex-service organisation representatives advise their members of funding arrangements;
- the Training Information Program (TIP). Information on the BEST program is incorporated into some TIP training sessions held in the States;

- the Department of Veterans' Affairs website. All details, including the application form, guidelines and contact details as well as an information sheet, are on the Department of Veterans' Affairs website; and
- letter mail out advising of forthcoming BEST application periods. The mail out is circulated to existing grantees notifying them of forthcoming BEST funding.
Â· Veteran and Community Grants - The Veteran & Community Grants are not advertised in the commercial media. However, Veteran & Community Grants are promoted by:

- the Department of Veterans' Affairs State Office staff, Veterans' Affairs Network (VAN) Office Staff and Community Advisers. Information about Veteran & Community Grants are disseminated at this level through local visits, forums (such as ex-service organisation grant workshops), mail outs and newsletter articles directed at ex-service and targeted community organisations;
- the Grantslink website, an all of government website which has a direct link to the Veteran & Community Grants site on the Department of Veterans' Affairs website; and

- the Department of Veterans' Affairs website. All details, including the application form, guidelines and contact details as well as an information sheet, are on the Department of Veterans' Affairs website.
Â· Saluting Their Service - Saluting Their Service is not advertised in the general commercial media. However, Saluting Their Service is promoted by:
- the Department of Veterans' Affairs disseminating information to community and ex-service organisations, local government authorities and other bodies such as museums and schools;
- Federal Members of Parliament disseminating information in their electorates, directly to organisations and through media releases and electoral newsletters;
- the Grantslink website, an all of government website which has a direct link to the Saluting Their Service site on the Department of Veterans' Affairs website;

- the Department of Veterans' Affairs website. All details, including the application form, guidelines and contact details as well as an information sheet, are on the Department of Veterans' Affairs website; and
- on occasions, paid advertisements in industry specific publications, for example local government authority journals and educational publications.
Â· Grants-in-Aid - No advertising is undertaken with the Grants-in-Aid program but the application form is available on the Department of Veterans' Affairs website.
(4) (a) (b) (c) (d) (e) I am not prepared to authorise the expenditure of resources and effort that would be involved in breaking down the information sought into the electoral divisions requested

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 20 August 2002:

question.para: (1) How many (a) full time permanent staff, (b) part time permanent staff, (c) full time contract staff and (d) part time contract staff were employed by (i) the Minister's Department and (ii) agencies within the Minister's portfolio as at (A) 30 March 1996 and (B) 30 June 2002.

(2) For each category of engagement referred to in part (1) and employed by (a) the Minister's Department and (b) agencies within the Minister's portfolio, where were such persons located in (i) 30 March 1996 and (ii) 30 June 2002.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr Howard
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: I am advised by my department as follows:

(1)(A) The information sought by the honourable member in relation to part (1)(A) and part (2)(i) of his question is not readily available and I am not prepared to authorise the use of the resources that would be required to provide that information. I am able to inform the honourable member, however, that data on APS staffing as at 30 June 1996 is contained in the Australian Public Service Statistical Bulletin 1995-1996 which is publicly available.

The honourable member should be aware, however, that changes in APS functions and administrative arrangements between 1996 and 2002 may not readily allow direct comparisons of the data for those years.
The information sought by the honourable member in relation to part (1)(B) and part (2) of his question is provided in the attached tables.
(1) Number of staff employed within the Prime Minister's portfolio as at 30 June 2002.

entry.para: Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet
Office of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security
Office of the Official Secretary to the Governor-General

answer.para: * Seven of the staff in category (c) and 1 in category (d) are employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984.
** Staff are employed under the Governor-General Act 1974.
(2) Location of staff within the Prime Minister's portfolio as at 30 June 2002.

entry.para: Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet
Office of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security
Office of the Official Secretary to the Governor-General

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 20 August 2002:

quote.para: (1) How many (a) full time permanent staff, (b) part time permanent staff, (c) full time contract staff and (d) part time contract staff were employed by (i) the Ministers Department and (ii) agencies within the Ministers portfolio as at (A) 30 March 1996 and (B) 30 June 2002.

(2) For each category of engagement referred to in part (1) and employed by (a) the Ministers Department and (b) agencies within the Ministers portfolio, where were such persons located in (i) 30 March 1996 and (ii) 30 June 2002.

talker.name: Vaile, Mark, MP
Mr Vaile

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 28 August 2002:

question.para: (1) Who are the members of the Settlement Planning Committees in each State and Territory.
(2) How many meetings did each committee hold in the latest year for which data is available.
(3) Are the committees expected to consult formally with the community and interested stakeholders; If so, what mechanisms exist for them to actually do so.

(4) What specific roles, if any, do the committees have in (a) planning and (b) funding processes under (i) the Community Settlement Services Scheme, (ii) the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy and (iii) the Migrant Resource Centre program.
(5) Is each committee required to produce an annual report on its activities; If so, to whom are these reports provided; If not, why not.

talker.name: Hardgrave, Gary, MP
Mr Hardgrave
talker.role: Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The settlement planning committees comprise representatives of government agencies at the Commonwealth, State/Territory and local government levels, and representatives of non-government agencies that provide settlement services such as health, housing, education, training, employment and other social services to migrants and refugees. There are 10 settlement planning committees, one in each State and Territory, and two regional committees.

(2) In the calendar year, January 2001 to December 2001, the following settlement planning committee meetings were held in each State/Territory: Victoria - 4; NSW - 4; Queensland - 4; Western Australia - 4; South Australia - 4; Northern Territory - 4; Tasmania - 6; and, ACT - 3. (In addition, 3 meetings were held in each of the two rural settlement planning committees: Riverina Region and Albury-Wodonga).

(3) All settlement planning committees use community and stakeholder input to help identify and prioritise the needs of migrants and refugees, particularly in designing their State/Territory settlement plans. The form of consultation is a matter for each individual committee. However, the methods adopted by committees include:
- community representation on the settlement planning committee itself;
- community consultation workshops to identify annual planning priorities;
- community participation through established working parties that feed into the work of the larger settlement planning committee; and/or
- the use of proformas to gather information from community representatives (eg. via Community Project officers in the local Migrant Resource Centre or Migrant Service Agency).

(4) (a) Settlement planning committees have a broad planning function which involves ascertaining the priority settlement needs of migrants and refugees, who is responsible for meeting those needs, developing strategies accordingly and monitoring outcomes of the strategies put in place. Settlement planning committees identify gaps and needs in service delivery. Those areas of need are taken into consideration by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) in assessing applications for DIMIA funding, and in the general planning on which services are required.

(b) In addition, each State/Territory has specifically convened Funding Advisory Committees, comprising Commonwealth and State/Territory representatives (of which some are also members of settlement planning committees). Funding Advisory Committees determine:
- whether an application for the Community Settlement Services Scheme would be more appropriately funded by an agency other than DIMIA; and
- whether an application for the Community Settlement Services Scheme duplicates existing services.

Funding Advisory Committees have no role in the assessment of tenders for contracts under the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy or the provision of core funding to Migrant Resource Centres/Migrant Service Agencies.

(5) Each settlement planning committee is required to report to the Ministerial Council on Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (MCIMA) on achievements against settlement plans and in particular against the National Settlement Priorities, local priorities and the annual National Settlement Project. Each settlement planning committee also reports biannually to the Standing Committee on Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (SCIMA) on the development of, and outcomes from, the National Settlement Project. The National Settlement Project for 2002 is, `Promoting awareness of the needs of newly arrived young people, particularly refugees'.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, upon notice on, 29 August 2002:

quote.para: What steps are being undertaken by the Government to implement the proposed ban on the use and importation of chrysotile asbestos?

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr Abbott
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The May 2001 meeting of the Workplace Relations Ministers' Council (WRMC) agreed to the imposition of a ban on the import and use of chrysotile asbestos no later than 31 December 2003. WRMC also asked the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (NOHSC) to undertake essential consultation to facilitate imposing bans on all other forms of asbestos.
Since that time the following steps have been taken on a national basis to prohibit the use and importation of chrysotile asbestos:

Â· At the WRMC meeting in September 2001, Ministers endorsed proposed amendments to Schedule 2 (Substances prohibited for specific uses) of the NOHSC National Model Regulations for the Control of Workplace Hazardous Substances (Model Regulations), to prohibit the use of chrysotile, crocidolite and amosite asbestos. This meeting also endorsed implementation arrangements to effect the ban on chrysotile asbestos, including developing a nationally consistent approach to exemptions and a proposal to develop recommendations for prohibiting all other forms of asbestos.

Â· Prohibition on the import of asbestos and any exemptions is to be effected through regulations to be made under the Customs Act 1901 following completion of public consultation by NOHSC. The World Trade Organisation was duly notified in September 2001 of Australia's intention to prohibit chrysotile asbestos.

Â· Consistent with WRMC's approval NOHSC declared the amendments to the Model Regulations on 17 October 2001 listing the uses prohibited. The States and Territories will make appropriate regulations or legislate to bring the prohibition on the use of chrysotile and other forms of asbestos into effect.
Â· Following the implementation of the prohibition, Australian Design Rules are to be revised in 2004 prohibiting the use of asbestos in brake linings in motor vehicles.

Â· In May 2002 NOHSC reported to WRMC that all jurisdictions were on track to implement the prohibition from 31 December 2003. WRMC also agreed to nationally consistent arrangements for exemptions to the prohibition through the development of a National List of Exemptions.

Â· In June 2002, NOHSC released a public consultation discussion paper on the proposed National List of Exemptions. Comments on the discussion paper closed on 13 September 2002. In the same month NOHSC also initiated a review of the exposure standard for chrysotile asbestos.

Â· NOHSC is to report to WRMC in November 2002 on further progress towards implementation of the prohibition, including all forms of asbestos, arising from its public consultations and consideration of proposed exemption arrangements.
The Government's responsibilities in relation to the prohibition of the use of chrysotile include Commonwealth employment and the shipping industry.
In relation to Commonwealth employment:

Â· On 26 September 2001, the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Commission (the Commission) endorsed that the prohibition of use of chrysotile and other forms of asbestos is to be as consistent as possible with the NOHSC model regulations which prohibit the use of chrysotile and other forms of asbestos.

Â· Changes to Schedule 1A (Scheduled carcinogenic substances) and the listing of chrysotile in Part 2 (Permitted circumstances for handling of certain hazardous substances with carcinogenic properties) Schedule 1 (Hazardous substances) of the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) (National Standards) Regulations 1994 are currently being developed to enable the prohibition to be in place in Commonwealth employment by 31 December 2003.

Â· Comcare has undertaken consultation with Commonwealth employers about the phase out of asbestos to ensure all can comply with the prohibition from 31 December 2003. All Commonwealth employers have received information from Comcare alerting them to the health effects of exposure to asbestos and informing them of the impending prohibition. Comcare is working closely with various Commonwealth employers to assist compliance with the prohibition.

Â· This consultation and general discussion has increased awareness of the pending prohibitions. Comcare will develop explanatory material for approval and release by the Commission to accompany the implementation of the ban. The information will be distributed to all employers in the jurisdiction and is accessible from the Comcare website.

In relation to the shipping industry, the Seacare Authority is to consider in November 2002 proposals for a regulation under the Occupational Health and Safety (Maritime Industry) 1993 Act to prohibit the use of chrysotile and other forms of asbestos with effect from 31 December 2003. The Authority's considerations will be informed by the work which has been undertaken for the prohibition in Commonwealth employment.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 August 2002:

question.para: (1) How many National Service Medal applications have been received by the Medals Directorate of the Minister's Department.
(2) How many National Service Medals have been awarded to applicants in (a) January, (b) February, (c) March, (d) April, (e) May, (f) June and (g) July 2002.
(3) What is the average time taken to process applications for the National Service Medal.
(4) How large is the backlog of National Service Medal applications.

(5) Did the Minister's Department employ any extra staff to cope with the workload caused by the National Service Medal; if so, how many extra full time equivalent positions were created; if not, why not.

(6) Does the Minister have any plans in the short term to increase resources to the Medals Directorate to reduce the backlog of National Service Medal applications and to reduce stress on the existing staff.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) As of 3 September 2002, approximately 100,000 applications for the Anniversary of National Service 1951-1972 Medal (ANSM) have been received.
(2) (a) As the initial presentation of medals took place on 10 February 2002 to the next of kin of those that were killed in action in Vietnam, no medals were issued in January.
(b) February 3,557
(c) March 10,043
(d) April 5,868
(f) June 3,707
(g) July 5,030
(3) On average, it takes 6 months to process applications for the ANSM from the time they are received to the time they are dispatched.
(5) Yes, four.
(6) Yes, two.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 16 May 2002:

quote.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the practice of government affiliated blood collection agencies in China pooling blood to extract plasma and then returning the pooled blood to donors to prevent anaemia.
(2) Is he able to say whether this practice has led to infection of blood donor supplies by individuals with HIV and AIDS.
(3) Is he able to say whether, despite a recent Chinese central government crackdown, local officials persist in selling tainted blood.

(4) Are Australian authorities aware that Henan province was the epicentre of this blood selling business and in some villages over 60% of residents are now HIV positive; if so, is his Department able to confirm whether in that province, in a majority of families, a majority of adults have died and only youth or elderly remain.

(5) Is it expected that at the forthcoming 16th Party Congress of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), Li Chang Chun, the Henan CCP Chief and protÃ©gÃ© of Premier Jiang Zemin, will be elevated as Vice Premier.
(6) Has the Australian Government offered to provide Australian public education programs on the prevention of the spread of HIV and AIDS to national and regional governments in China.
(7) What steps, if any, has the Australian Government taken to warn Australian tourists to China of the danger of accessing local blood supplies in the event of being involved in accidents.

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr Downer
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) and (2) The Government is aware of credible reports that in a number of Chinese provinces, predominantly in central China, there has been a practice of people selling their blood and plasma to commercial blood processing companies. The practice of pooling the blood, separating the plasma and then re-injecting red blood cells back into donors has led to the rapid spread of HIV in these areas.

(3) In 1998 China passed a blood donation law prohibiting commercial blood donations and stipulating that all blood collected for medical transfusions should be from voluntary donations. The Government is aware of reports that some blood-collecting companies continue to operate illegally, particularly in remote, impoverished areas where authorities find it harder to prevent the practice.

(4) The Government is aware that the practice of commercial blood collection existed in Henan Province, though the practice was prevalent in a number of central Chinese provinces in the 1990s. Figures vary on the current extent of HIV infection in Henan province; estimates range from the Chinese Ministry of Health's figure of 150,000 to above 1 million HIV-infected people. The UN theme group on HIV/AIDS in China quotes reports from local residents that in some villages in the province more than 80% of adults are HIV positive.
(5) The Government cannot speculate on this.

(6) Australia is funding projects to combat the spread of HIV/AIDS in nine provinces in China. All projects include the provision of health education programs to improve knowledge of HIV/AIDS prevention and control among the general population and special programs for high-risk groups. Several of these projects also include components supporting the national government's agenda for the implementation of safe blood supply and reducing risk of transfusing infected blood.

(7) The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade reviewed the travel advice for China at the end of September 2002. It advises that the availability of reliable medical care in China is limited, particularly outside of major cities. Travellers are strongly advised to have the appropriate health insurance in the event they need to reach a reliable medical centre.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 17 September 2002:

question.para: In view of the very significant increases in property values in Australia since 1996, will the Howard Government undertake a review of the assets test with a view to increasing the threshold as it currently applies in the calculation of age pensions; if so, when; if not, why not.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for Family and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: The Honourable Member may not be aware, but the Hawke Labor Government introduced the assets means test on age pensions in 1985. The assets test threshold is adjusted in line with the Consumer Price Index (CPI) and normally adjustments are made in July of each year. Also, the asset amount at which no pension is payable increases in line with pension increases.
Further, the Honourable Member may not be aware that as the principal home is exempt from the assets test, pensioners are not affected by increases in the value of their home.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 17 September 2002:

quote.para: (1) Is he aware that the Shell Company is considering withdrawing from the Greater Sunrise Gas Project.

(2) If Shell does withdraw, what are the implications for (a) the remaining venture partners and their capacity to exploit the resource, (b) the campaign to bring Sunrise gas on-shore for both industrial development in northern Australia and to provide a new source of gas for the south east market and (c) the retention lease of the venture partners.
(3) Will the Government act to ensure âuse it or lose itâ principles are appropriately applied to the field.
(4) Will the Government use the period in which ownership arrangements are being negotiated to aggressively pursue the on-shore option.

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
Mr Ian Macfarlane
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) I am aware of newspaper articles that assert Shell is considering to quit the Sunrise gas project. Such assertions have been rejected by Shell. Indeed, on 6 September 2002, an article in The Australian Newspaper titled âShell Poised To Dump Sunriseâ drew an immediate response from Shell in the form of a Media Release later in the day.

Shell confirmed its commitment to develop Sunrise describing Sunrise as an âimportant gas resource for Shell, and the joint venture companies having spent already over $200 million trying to develop the fieldâ. The Media Release outlined that Shell is currently engaged with its Joint Venture partners (Woodside, Phillips and Osaka Gas) in considering two development options for Sunrise being the floating LNG and the domestic gas option.
(2) (3) and (4) Not applicable. See answer 1.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources: International Energy Branch
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 923)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 17 September 2002:

question.para: Further to the answer to part (1) of question No. 539 (Hansard, 19 August 2002, page 5149), to which Division was the International Energy Branch transferred, why was it transferred and on what date was it transferred.

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
Mr Ian Macfarlane
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The International Energy Branch was transferred to the then Petroleum and International Energy Division. It was transferred to that Division in order to balance the workload responsibilities amongst the Divisions that existed within the organisation structure which existed at that time. The transfer took effect from 1 January 2002.

Since then, there has been a major Departmental reorganisation, which saw the then three Divisions which had responsibility for resources and energy issues reduce to two Divisions. As part of this major reorganisation, the International Energy Branch was included in the Energy and Environment Division structure.

subdebateinfo.title: Centre for the Analysis and Dissemination of Demonstrated Energy Technologies
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 941)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 19 September 2002:

question.para: (1) Does the Government still fund CADDET through his Department; if not, why not.
(2) Where can those who relied on the information available through this program now source this information.
(3) When did his Department cease producing the Australian Energy News (AEN) magazine.
(4) What was the basis of this decision and what alternative options are available to those who subscribed to AEN.

talker.name: Macfarlane, Ian, MP
Mr Ian Macfarlane
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Government's membership fee for CADDET is paid to the end of March 2003. Funding for domestic operating arrangements, including the distribution of CADDET materials to subscribers ceased on 30 June 2002. Due to budgetary constraints the Department is no longer able to fund this activity.

(2) Information on international energy technologies and programs, including CADDET publications, will continue to be available in electronic format on the following websites www.caddet-ee.org, www.caddet-re.org and www.greentie.org.
(3) The last Australian Energy News magazine was the June 2002 edition.

(4) Due to budgetary constraints on the portfolio fore 2002/03, Australian Energy News is no longer able to be published. Information about developments in Commonwealth energy policy, programs and related activities can continue to be accessed on the Department's website at www.industry.gov.au. As usual the Department will continue to be proactive in communicating with all stakeholders and responding to questions.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Ageing, upon notice, on 25 September 2002:

quote.para: Is the Poise brand of incontinence products subsidised by the Commonwealth Government while the Tenia brand is not; if so, why.

talker.name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
Mr Andrews
talker.role: Minister for Ageing

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Both Depend Poise and Tena brand products are available under the Continence Aids Assistance Scheme.
